user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimerSet:
```c
int32 OS_TimerSet(osal_id_t timer_id, uint32 start_time, uint32 interval_time)
{
    OS_timecb_internal_record_t *timecb;
    int32                        return_code;
    osal_objtype_t               objtype;
    osal_id_t                    dedicated_timebase_id;
    OS_object_token_t            token;

    dedicated_timebase_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    ARGCHECK(start_time < (UINT32_MAX / 2), OS_TIMER_ERR_INVALID_ARGS);
    ARGCHECK(interval_time < (UINT32_MAX / 2), OS_TIMER_ERR_INVALID_ARGS);
    ARGCHECK(start_time != 0 || interval_time != 0, OS_TIMER_ERR_INVALID_ARGS);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, timer_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        timecb = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timecb_table, token);

        OS_TimeBaseLock_Impl(&timecb->timebase_token);

        if ((timecb->flags & TIMECB_FLAG_DEDICATED_TIMEBASE) != 0)
        {
            dedicated_timebase_id = OS_ObjectIdFromToken(&timecb->timebase_token);
        }

        timecb->wait_time     = (int32)start_time;
        timecb->interval_time = (int32)interval_time;

        OS_TimeBaseUnlock_Impl(&timecb->timebase_token);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    /*
     * If the timer uses a dedicated time base, then also change that to the same interval.
     *
     * This is not perfect in the sense that the update is not all done atomically.  If this
     * is not the first call to TimerSet, then weirdness can happen:
     *  - a timer tick could occur between setting the callback times above and now
     *  - the call to OS_TimeBaseSet() could fail leaving us in a mixed state
     *
     * However, the notion of multiple TimerSet() calls is a gray area to begin with, since
     * timer ticks can occur at any moment - there is never a guarantee your new TimerSet values
     * will get applied before the old timer expires.  Therefore by definition an application
     * MUST be able to handle a possible "spurious" callback in these circumstances.
     */
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS && OS_ObjectIdDefined(dedicated_timebase_id))
    {
        return_code = OS_TimeBaseSet(dedicated_timebase_id, start_time, interval_time);
    }
    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimerSet:
typedef struct
{
    char              timer_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    uint32            flags;
    OS_object_token_t timebase_token;
    osal_id_t         prev_cb;
    osal_id_t         next_cb;
    uint32            backlog_resets;
    int32             wait_time;
    int32             interval_time;
    OS_ArgCallback_t  callback_ptr;
    void *            callback_arg;
} OS_timecb_internal_record_t
...
OS_timecb_internal_record_t OS_timecb_table[OS_MAX_TIMERS]
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
void OS_TimeBaseLock_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_timebase_table, *token);

    pthread_mutex_lock(&impl->handler_mutex);
}
...
void OS_TimeBaseUnlock_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_timebase_table, *token);

    pthread_mutex_unlock(&impl->handler_mutex);
}
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
#define TIMECB_FLAG_DEDICATED_TIMEBASE 0x1
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No pointer-to-object usages in the provided OS_TimerSet implementation appear to violate MISRA C:2023 Rule 8.13. Reasons why other fragments do NOT need investigation: 

- The local pointer declaration OS_timecb_internal_record_t *timecb is used to modify the timer control block (writes to wait_time and interval_time and reads/writes other fields). Because the code intentionally modifies the pointed-to object, the pointer must not point to a const-qualified type.

- The local variable token (OS_object_token_t token) is passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById(&token) as an output parameter; it must be writable by that function, so it cannot be const.

- OS_ObjectIdFromToken is declared to take a const OS_object_token_t * (see additional code) and is already const-correct; calling it with &timecb->timebase_token is therefore compliant.

- OS_TimeBaseLock_Impl and OS_TimeBaseUnlock_Impl are declared to take const OS_object_token_t * and are therefore const-correct; passing the address of the (non-const) token is allowed and does not violate Rule 8.13.

- The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro returns a pointer to the table element. The timer control block table (OS_timecb_table) elements are intentionally mutable (the code writes to fields), so the returned pointer must not be to a const-qualified type.

- Calls that take pointers (e.g., OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIdRelease) are either output/management operations that require writable tokens or are already declared with const where appropriate in the provided additional code.

- The callback_arg field is declared as void * in the record and is intended for use by callbacks; whether it should be const depends on external callback semantics and cannot be determined from this function alone.

Given the provided code and related declarations, there are no pointer declarations/usages in OS_TimerSet that should obviously be changed to point to const-qualified types without breaking required semantics; therefore no suspicious fragments are reported.
